entry.title: Liberia quarantines an area where new Ebola case appeared
entry.summary:
Health workers leave after they took a blood specimen from a child to test for the Ebola virus in a area were a 17-year old boy died from the virus on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia, Tuesday, June 30, 2015.

Liberian authorities on Tuesday quarantined an area where the corpse of the boy was found, sparking fears this West African country could face another outbreak of the disease nearly two months after being declared Ebola-free.

entry.title: Liberia quarantines community where corpse tested for Ebola
entry.summary: The corpse of a 17-year-old man has tested positive for Ebola in Liberia, but no other cases have been reported, the country's deputy health minister said late Monday, June 29, 2015.

entry.title: Sierra Leone police raid funeral, arrest 13 for organising unsafe burial
entry.summary:
Police in Ebola-hit Sierra Leone have raided a funeral and arrested 13 people suspected of organising an unsafe burial, risking spreading the disease, officers said.

Alimamy Kamara, head of the National Ebola Response Centre (NERC) in charge of Freetown and the surrounding area, said last week that people organising unsafe burials risked two-year jail terms.

The NERC said later on Tuesday that health authorities had wrongly reported Ebola as the cause of a baby's death in the eastern district of Kailahun, which was declared free of the virus weeks ago.

entry.title: Liberia reports first Ebola death since country declared free of virus
entry.summary: "A 17-year-old corpse was tested positive for Ebola virus. This took place in Margibi County. There is no need to panic. The corpse has been buried and our contact tracing has started work," said Nyenswah.

entry.title: Liberia announces fresh Ebola death
entry.summary:
A health worker injects a woman with an Ebola vaccine during a trial in Monrovia, February 2, 2015.

MONROVIA A Liberian has died of Ebola in the first recorded case since the country at the heart of an epidemic was declared free of the virus on May 9, Deputy Health Minister Tolbert Nyenswah said on Tuesday.

entry.title: Rapid-detection Ebola test could be game-changer
entry.summary:
A new rapid-detection test that diagnoses Ebola within minutes could improve treatment of the deadly virus and help health care workers contain outbreaks, researchers say.

At two treatment centers in Sierra Leone, 106 people suspected of having Ebola underwent both rapid-detection and conventional testing in February.

The rapid-detection test accurately diagnosed all confirmed cases of Ebola, the study published June 25 in The Lancet found.

entry.title: Ebola patient thanks hospital staff
entry.summary:
An Army Reservist who has been discharged from hospital after being successfully treated for Ebola said it was thanks to medical staff that she is alive.

She joined the Army Reserves in 2013 as a staff nurse and volunteered to help care for Ebola patients in Sierra Leone, arriving there last month.

entry.title: Tekmira says Ebola drug unlikely to work in study
entry.summary:
The company has been studying the drug in Ebola patients in Sierra Leone.

Tekmira is also running an early-stage trial of a drug called TKM-Ebola, which targets a slightly different strain of the virus.

entry.title: Need a miracle cure? Visit North Korea: Impoverished nation claims it has antidote for MERS, Ebola and AIDS
entry.summary: The authoritarian, impoverished nation better known for pursuing a nuclear program despite global criticism announced Friday it has a drug that can prevent and cure MERS, Ebola, SARS and AIDS.

entry.title: North Korea claims 'cure' for Mers, Aids and Ebola
entry.summary: The authoritarian, impoverished nation announced it has a drug that can prevent and cure Mers, Ebola, Sars and Aids.

entry.title: After Ebola, world still unprepared for global pandemic: MSF
entry.summary:
Late and slow international response, the absence of solid leadership as well as the lack of treatments and vaccines are a recurrent scenario in many of today's health emergencies and are not unique to the Ebola epidemic, the medical charity said.

While Liberia was recently declared Ebola-free, a spike in new cases in Guinea has stoked concerns the virus could spread again.

World leaders from Germany, the United States, Britain, France, Canada, Italy and Japan will meet in Germany next week, and are expected to discuss Ebola and neglected diseases, among other issues, MSF said.

entry.title: City paid $30K to settle Ebola fears lawsuit over girl, 7
entry.summary:
(AP) - The insurance carrier for a Connecticut city paid $30,000 to settle a lawsuit filed by the family of a third-grader who was barred from school for several days because of Ebola fears.

entry.title: Ebola could hit again and we would hardly do better: MSF
entry.summary: "The reality today is if Ebola were to hit on scale it did in August and September, we would hardly do much better than we did the last time around," Joanne Liu said on the sidelines of a meeting on Ebola in Dakar.

entry.title: Sierra Leone imposes Ebola curfew for northern districts
entry.summary: FREETOWN Sierra Leone is introducing new curfews for two northern districts after a spike in new Ebola cases to the highest level in months, President Ernest Bai Koroma said on Friday.

entry.title: As Ebola disappears, no useful data seen from vaccine trials, says WHO
entry.summary: With Ebola nearly stamped out in West Africa, vaccine trials will probably fail to provide enough useful data on how well they protect people against the deadly virus, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Tuesday.

entry.title: Japanese Ebola test gives results in 11 minutes: researcher
entry.summary:
A Japanese research team said on Thursday it had developed a field test for Ebola that gives results in just over 11 minutes -- down from the 90-minute test used now.

If Ebola is present, DNA specific to the virus is amplified by the action of the primers.

entry.title: Kailahun Ebola case report was a mistake, says Sierra Leone
entry.summary: Sierra Leone said on Tuesday that it had mistakenly reported an Ebola positive case in Kailahun, a former hotspot for the virus which has not seen a case for nearly four months.

entry.title: G7 states vow to wipe out Ebola but offer little concrete action
G7 states vow to wipe out Ebola but offer little concrete action
entry.summary:
KRUEN, Germany (Reuters) - Leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations pledged on Monday to wipe out Ebola but offered little in terms of concrete action, disappointing non-governmental organizations.

Charity Oxfam was also disappointed, saying fighting pandemics like Ebola required "more than simply putting the emergency services on standby".

entry.title: World Health Organization approves 1st quick test for Ebola

entry.title: Fiancee chronicles love, life with man who died of Ebola in Texas
entry.summary:
DALLAS - Thomas Eric Duncan became the face of a crisis when he was diagnosed with Ebola in the United States, but he was simply "Eric" to his fiancee, Louise Troh, who said she has endured threats and battled nightmares since his death in October.

"He did not mean to come here with Ebola," said Troh.

"People are calling me the 'Ebola man's wife,'" she said.

entry.title: Emails: UN health agency resisted declaring Ebola emergency

entry.title: Ban Ki-moon urges final push on Ebola
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon says as long as there is one Ebola case in West Africa "all countries are at risk", and has urged nations to support the final battles to wipe out the disease in Sierra Leone and Guinea.

entry.title: UN chief urges all nations to help end Ebola in West Africa
entry.summary:
Liberia, once the worst affected country, is now Ebola free, but Ban warned that in Sierra Leone and Guinea "the battle has not yet been won" and "any lapse in vigilance could allow the virus to spread."

"We must also translate lessons learned from this Ebola outbreak into stronger national and international systems to prevent and respond to health crises," he said.

entry.title: UN chief urges every nation to help end Ebola in West Africa, saying 1 case puts all at risk

entry.title: 'Ebola will return', veteran scientist warns
entry.summary:
Now, amid a decline in a west African outbreak that has taken more than 11,000 lives, Muyembe warns that Ebola will strike again in the future and that the deadly virus poses "a threat to the whole world".

"We drew blood from people recovering from Ebola, and injected it into eight sick patients. Seven of them survived, even though there was an 80 percent mortality rate," he said.

"Ebola can strike anywhere, and we need to be vigilant. The United States and Europe must understand that Africa is their shield."

entry.title: Merkel: Global catastrophe plan needed after Ebola crisis
entry.summary: "If we react faster, and act faster, we will manage to better prevent a crisis like Ebola the next time," Merkel told the assembly, which is the WHO's decision-making body.

entry.title: Merkel: Global catastrophe plan needed after Ebola crisis
entry.summary:
BERLIN (AP) - The Ebola crisis in western Africa showed the world in a painful way that a global catastrophe plan is needed to deal with future epidemics, German Chancellor Angela Merkel said Monday.

"The struggle (against Ebola) is only won if there are no new cases and if we have learned the lessons from this crisis: we should have reacted earlier," Merkel told the 68th World Health Assembly in Geneva.

entry.title: Fiancee of Ebola victim hopes memoir closes chapter
entry.summary:
The fiancee of the first Ebola victim in the U.S. hopes her memoir provides some resolution to a story that spanned two decades, from Africa to a Dallas hospital.

The fiancee of the first Ebola victim in the U.S., Thomas Eric Duncan, hopes "My Spirit Took You In" provides some resolution to a story that spanned two decades, from a border town in Ivory Coast to a Dallas hospital.

"Suppose Eric had not come here to become the face of Ebola, then the whole of Liberia would be in darkness," she told The Associated Press in her first interview since his death.

"I was never thinking that he had Ebola. When he got sick, I thought, let me call the ambulance and just for their protection, tell them that he was from a country with this disease. That's all. I'm not a doctor," Jallah says.

entry.title: Tekmira Ebola drug succeeds in small monkey study

Scientists to share real-time genetic data on deadly MERS, Ebola
entry.summary: LONDON - Genetic sequence data on two of the deadliest yet most poorly understood viruses are to be made available to researchers worldwide in real time as scientists seek to speed up understanding of Ebola and MERS infections.

entry.title: Scientists to share real-time genetic data on deadly MERS, Ebola
entry.summary:
The gene sequences, already available for MERS cases and soon to come in the case of Ebola, will be posted on the website virological.org for anyone to see, access and use.

As part of the same gene sequencing project, Ian Goodfellow from the University of Cambridge is in Sierra Leone working with the government there to make similar data on the Ebola virus available on virological.org as soon as possible.

He plans to collect samples from Ebola patients, sequence them in a matter of hours and process the data to make the viral genome sequences in weeks -- a process that could take months if samples were to be bought back to Britain for analysis.

entry.title: WHO admits failings during Ebola crisis

The World Health Organization has admitted several failings during the Ebola crisis.

The World Health Organization has admitted serious failings in its handling of the Ebola crisis and pledged reforms to enable it to do better next time, its leadership said in a statement seen by Reuters on Sunday.

entry.title: Ebola outbreak still a global emergency: WHO
entry.summary:
LONDON -- The World Health Organization says the year-long Ebola outbreak in West Africa still qualifies as an international emergency even though the number of cases has plummeted.

Dr. Bruce Aylward, who is leading WHO's Ebola response, said the decline appeared to be real, rather than just "a pothole on the bumpy road to get to zero cases."

During a press briefing in Geneva on Friday, Aylward said WHO's Ebola emergency committee believes the risk of the virus spreading globally appears to be dropping even though officials still don't know where the virus is spreading in most cases in Guinea and Sierra Leone.

He said the designation of Ebola as a global emergency is also necessary to speed up paperwork for the ongoing experimental drug and vaccine trials in West Africa.

Study finds no sign Ebola virus is mutating out of control
entry.summary:
WASHINGTON (Reuters) - There is no sign the Ebola virus is mutating in an accelerated way that could make it more virulent or thwart vaccines or drugs under development despite some earlier fears to the contrary, researchers said on Thursday.

The biggest Ebola outbreak to date, centered in three West African countries, has killed more than 10,000 people but is showing signs of waning.

The routine genetic changes observed indicate the viral mutations are not likely to affect diagnostic testing or the effectiveness of experimental Ebola vaccines or drugs, the researchers said.

There are no approved vaccines or medicines for Ebola.

entry.title: Last Ebola patient is released in Liberia
entry.summary:
MONROVIA, Liberia (AP) - Liberia released its last Ebola patient, a 58-year old teacher, from a treatment center on Thursday, beginning its countdown to being declared Ebola free.

Yardolo said she had been admitted to the Chinese-run Ebola treatment center in the Paynesville district of Monrovia on Feb. 18.

There are no other confirmed cases of Ebola in the country, and as such Liberia can begin to count up to 42 days to be declared Ebola free in keeping with World Health Organization protocols and standards, Nyenswah said Wednesday.

entry.title: Liberia releases last Ebola patient; Countdown to being declared Ebola free begins
entry.summary: MONROVIA, Liberia (AP) " Liberia releases last Ebola patient; Countdown to being declared Ebola free begins.

entry.title: WHO to begin large-scale testing of Ebola vaccine in Guinea
entry.summary: The health agency's vaccination strategy in Guinea aims to create a buffer zone around an Ebola case to prevent its further spread?

entry.title: WHO to begin large-scale testing of Ebola vaccine in Guinea
entry.summary:
LONDON (AP) - The World Health Organization will start large-scale testing of an experimental Ebola vaccine in Guinea on Saturday to see how effective it might be in preventing future outbreaks of the deadly virus.

The West African nations of Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have been hardest hit in the yearlong Ebola outbreak, which is estimated to have left more than 9,800 people dead.

In a statement Thursday, the U.N. health agency said the vaccine study will focus on Basse Guinee, the region that has Guinea's most Ebola cases.

The agency said the spread of Ebola remains "widespread" in Sierra Leone and noted that cases have jumped both there and in Guinea.

WHO said only about half of new Ebola patients in Guinea are connected to known cases, meaning that health officials are unable to track where the disease is spreading in the other half of cases.

entry.title: After Ebola ban, N. Korea opens marathon to foreigners
entry.summary: TOKYO (AP) - After lifting travel restrictions it imposed because of concerns over the Ebola virus, North Korea says foreigners can now take part in one of its most popular tourist events - the annual Pyongyang marathon, a travel agency said Thursday.

entry.title: After Ebola ban, N. Korea opens marathon to foreigners
entry.summary: Even though no cases of Ebola had been reported anywhere near North Korea, the country shut out foreign tourists in October with some of the strictest Ebola regulations in the world, including saying that only local runners would be allowed into the marathon in April.

entry.title: West African leaders urge Ebola 'Marshall Plan'
entry.summary: The countries at the center of the Ebola epidemic are forecast to lose 12 percent of their combined gross domestic product this year, according to World Bank estimates.

entry.title: Ohio bridal shop linked to Ebola survivor will sell building
entry.summary: Dallas nurse Amber Vinson visited Coming Attractions Bridal & Formal in Akron days before she was diagnosed with Ebola last fall.

entry.title: Ohio bridal shop linked to Ebola survivor will sell building
entry.summary: AKRON, Ohio (AP) - A northeast Ohio bridal shop that was linked to an Ebola survivor and later announced plans to close has put its building up for sale.

entry.title: Liberia calls for Ebola 'Marshall Plan' to rebuild economies
entry.summary:
Sirleaf told fellow regional leaders and delegates at an international conference on Ebola in Brussels that restoring economic growth in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone is a long-term and costly task.

Even if the number of new Ebola cases in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone has dropped markedly, bringing it down to zero will still take a significant effort.

entry.title: Liberia calls for Ebola 'Marshall Plan' to rebuild economies
entry.summary:
BRUSSELS (AP) - Liberia's president on Tuesday called for an Ebola "Marshall Plan" to help rebuild economies in West African nations devastated by the virus.

"We are talking about a Marshall Plan because Ebola is like a war," Guinea President Alpha Conde said.

entry.title: Report: As Ebola wanes, other countries remain vulnerable
entry.summary:
Impoverished countries like Chad know the only way to stay Ebola-free is to keep any infected people out.

The report said only Somalia is worse prepared than Chad for an epidemic such as Ebola.

After causing nearly 10,000 recorded deaths, the Ebola epidemic is waning in the three worst-hit countries, Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.

It found that 28 countries were worse off than Liberia, which has seen the most deaths from the Ebola epidemic that began in December 2013.

entry.title: North Korea lifts Ebola travel restrictions
entry.summary:
Officials in Pyongyang said the restrictions and quarantines would continue for visitors from Ebola-affected countries in Africa and those countries that have borders with them.

North Korean media had suggested the Ebola virus was created by the U.S. military for use as a biological weapon.

entry.title: North Korea lifts Ebola travel restrictions
entry.summary:
TOKYO (AP) - North Korea has lifted severe restrictions on foreign travel it imposed last year to keep the Ebola virus from crossing its borders.

"We have been informed by Air Koryo that North Korea's borders are now open for travel and the four-month long Ebola travel ban was lifted as of Monday," Uri Tours said.

entry.title: Ebola survivor leaves US after recovery to return to Africa
Ebola survivor leaves US after recovery to return to Africa
entry.summary: Nancy Writebol last summer became the second American infected with the Ebola virus while working at a hospital SIM supports in the Liberian capital of Monrovia.

entry.title: Nurse who survived Ebola sues Dallas hospital system
entry.summary:
Duncan, who contracted Ebola in his native Liberia but started showing symptoms during a trip to the U.S., died at the hospital.

On the first day Pham treated Duncan, when Ebola was suspected but not yet diagnosed, she wore a regular isolation gown, double gloves, a surgical mask with a plastic shield and double booties.

Pham says that after Duncan died, she was told that what she had worn was safe and that she had no risk of contracting Ebola.

She says he falsely claimed that the hospital was trained to manage Ebola and that he misrepresented the type of protective equipment that nurses wore while caring for Duncan.

entry.title: UN warns against complacency as Ebola fight enters new phase
entry.summary:
BRUSSELS (AP) " The United Nations is urging donors, organizations and countries fighting Ebola in West Africa not to give in to complacency as the death toll from the virus climbs toward 10,000.

But U.N. Special Envoy on Ebola David Nabarro said the fight has reached a "second phase, getting to zero, and it really is the hardest part."

"It's a really difficult, painstaking task," he said in Brussels, on the eve of a major international conference on Ebola expected to draw around 600 delegates, including the leaders of Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.

entry.title: Ebola survivor sues Dallas hospital over infection
entry.summary:
DALLAS - The first person infected with Ebola in the United States, nurse Nina Pham, sued a Texas hospital on Monday, saying it did not do enough to prevent her from contracting the deadly virus and invaded her privacy after she was diagnosed with it.

The suit claims that the THR's Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital did not initially provide adequate protective gear for medical staff or instructions on how to treat someone with Ebola.

entry.title: Ebola survivor sues Dallas hospital over infection
entry.summary: "I was hoping that THR would be more open and honest about everything that happened at the hospital, and the things they didn't do that led to me getting infected with Ebola. But that didn't happen and I felt I was left with no choice but to turn to the courts for help," Pham said in a statement.

entry.title: Nurse who survived Ebola sues Dallas hospital system
entry.summary: Pham says in her lawsuit that the hospital was unprepared to treat Ebola cases and that she was an unwitting pawn in its public relations campaign to restore its reputation.

entry.title: Nurse who survived Ebola sues Dallas hospital system
entry.summary: She contracted Ebola last fall while caring for Thomas Eric Duncan at Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital Dallas.

entry.title: Nurse who survived Ebola sues Dallas hospital system
entry.summary: "I was hoping that THR would be more open and honest about everything that happened at the hospital, and the things they didn't do that led to me getting infected with Ebola," she said.

entry.title: ?Used as a PR pawn?: Nurse who survived Ebola infection says Texas hospital failed her
entry.summary:
DALLAS - A 26-year-old nurse said in a newspaper interview that a hospital where she had worked in Dallas and its parent company failed her when she contracted Ebola while caring for the first person in the U.S. diagnosed with the deadly disease.

Pham and another nurse who worked at Texas Health Presbyterian, Amber Vinson, both became infected with Ebola after caring for Duncan, according to medical records released to The Associated Press.

entry.title: Nurse Treated For Ebola To Sue Texas Hospital
Sierra Leone's VP in self-quarantine after guard dies from Ebola
entry.summary:
Sierra Leone's vice-president has put himself in quarantine following the death from Ebola of one of his security guards.

Sam-Sumana voluntarily decided to quarantine himself for 21 days following the death from Ebola last Tuesday of one of his security personnel.

entry.title: Sierra Leone's Samuel Sam-Sumana in quarantine over Ebola worries
entry.summary:
Despite his quarantine, Sam-Sumana is set to become acting president later Sunday when President Ernest Bai Koroma leaves Sierra Leone to attend a EU conference on Ebola in Belgium.

Sam-Sumana's dramatic quarantine comes as Sierra Leone is experiencing a rise in new Ebola cases which prompted President Ernest Bai Koroma to reinstate restrictions on Saturday.

entry.title: Liberia lifts Ebola curfew and re-opens borders
Liberia to end Ebola curfew, open land border crossings
entry.summary: In a statement, the White House said President Barack Obama and Sirleaf would discuss the current Ebola response and the region's economic recovery plans during their Feb. 27 meeting.

entry.title: Liberia to end Ebola curfew, open land border crossings
entry.summary: Once the center of the worst Ebola outbreak in history, Liberia has recorded more than 9,000 confirmed, suspected and probable cases and 3,900 deaths.

entry.title: Liberia to end Ebola curfew, open land border crossings
entry.summary: MONROVIA, Liberia (AP) - Liberia's president on Friday ordered officials to lift an overnight curfew put in place six months ago to fight the Ebola epidemic and to reopen the country's land border crossings.

entry.title: WHO gives green light to 15-minute Ebola test
entry.summary: "The new test isn't about saving the lives of infected people, but it can help in the long run by making it easier and quicker to detect Ebola outbreaks."

entry.title: World Health Organization approves 1st quick test for Ebola
entry.summary:
BERLIN (AP) - The World Health Organization said Friday it has approved a quick test for Ebola that will dramatically cut the time it takes to determine - with reasonable accuracy - whether someone is infected with the deadly virus.

The new test can provide results within 15 minutes by detecting an Ebola protein.

entry.title: WHO approves 15-minute test for Ebola
entry.summary: "The new antigen test is not a gamechanger, but it is another useful tool in the fight against Ebola," said Dr Ben Neuman, lecturer in virology at the University of Reading.

entry.title: Health24.com | Breakthrough 15-minute Ebola test gets the nod
entry.summary: It is able to correctly identify about 92 percent of Ebola infected patients and 85 percent of those not infected with the virus, the WHO said.

entry.title: WHO approves breakthrough 15-minute Ebola test
entry.summary:
Geneva: The World Health Organization has approved the first rapid test for Ebola in a potential breakthrough for ending an epidemic that has killed almost 10,000 people in West Africa, it said on Friday.

The health charity Medecins Sans Frontieres, which has been at the forefront of the fight against Ebola, had expressed an interest, he said.

"The big fear has been that the market gets flooded with tests of unknown quality, or unknown performance, and with Ebola you need to know what are the limitations. A false positive has enormous implications. So does a false positive," she said.

entry.title: WHO approves 15-minute Ebola test
Fifteen-minute Ebola test approved
entry.summary: The first rapid blood test for Ebola has been approved for use by the World Health Organization.

entry.title: Liberia leader to visit US, 1st visit since Ebola outbreak
entry.summary:
WASHINGTON (AP) - The president of Liberia will visit the United States later this month, her first trip to the country since the Ebola outbreak in West Africa.

Since an Ebola outbreak began in December 2013 in the West African country of Guinea, there have been about 7,900 deaths, mostly in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone.

entry.title: Liberia reopens schools as Ebola wanes
entry.summary: A student has her body temperature checked as part of an Ebola screening at Don Bosco High School, as schools reopen in the Liberian capital, Monrovia.

entry.title: Liberia reopens schools as Ebola wanes
entry.summary:
Monrovia: Thousands of Liberian children in pristine uniforms flocked back to school for the first time in six months, after a after a closure designed to stem the spread of the worst Ebola outbreak in history.

"Authorities in the three countries are looking at catchup sessions and cancelling some school vacations. It will be challenging," said Sayo Aoki, education specialist in Ebola Emergencies at the UN Children's Fund.

entry.title: Liberia reopens schools as Ebola wanes
Sierra Leone promises probe into Ebola spending
entry.summary:
The report by Sierra Leone's Auditor General covered the months of May through October 2014, and looked at donations received directly by the government to fight Ebola.

More than 3,300 people have died from Ebola with nearly 11,000 cases over the past year in Sierra Leone, where transmission remains the highest in the world.

entry.title: Sierra Leone promises probe into Ebola spending
entry.summary:
As Ebola is being brought under control, Sierra Leone plans to re-open its schools at the end of March.

Neighboring Liberia reported just five confirmed Ebola cases last week and it reopened most of its schools Monday.

entry.title: Liberia schools reopen after 6-month Ebola closure
entry.summary:
"I am very happy to be counted among the living and I pray that Ebola be eradicated from this country."

Liberia has seen the highest death toll from the Ebola epidemic, with 3,800 killed.

entry.title: Liberia schools reopen after 6-month Ebola closure
entry.summary:
MONROVIA, Liberia (AP) - Students in Liberia began returning to the classroom Monday after a six-month closure during the Ebola epidemic that left thousands dead, lining up in their uniforms to have their temperatures taken before they could enter school gates.

A few, though, remained a bit fearful about returning even though there are just a handful of Ebola cases left in the country that once saw 100 new patients a week.

Nearly 9,200 people have died since the first Ebola deaths in rural Guinea in December 2013.
